dc:description:
The *PLCB4* gene is located on chromosome 20 at 20p12.3-p12.2 and encodes phospholipase C beta 4, which catalyzes the formation of inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate and diacylglycerol from phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate and functions as the direct signaling effector of the endothelin receptor type A (EDNRA)-Gq/11 pathway. EDNRA signaling plays a critical role in establishing the identity of neural crest cells that form the lower jaw and middle ear structures. The *PLCB4* gene was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive auriculocondylar syndrome (ACS) (MIM 620458) in 2013 (Gordon et al., PMID: 23315542). *PLCB4* has also been associated with an autosomal dominant form of ACS (MIM 614669). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working group, we found differences in inheritance pattern, phenotype, and molecular mechanism. Therefore, the relationships between *PLCB4* and autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive ACS were curated separately. 

Autosomal recessive ACS shares the same craniofacial malformations (distinctive question mark outer ear deformity, temporomandibular joint ankylosis, full cheeks, micrognathia, and microstomia) as the dominant form, with additional extra-cranial features that commonly include swallowing problems, GERD, laryngomalacia, central sleep apnea, and genital hypertrophy. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included five unrelated patients from five publications (PMID: 23315542; Kido et al., 2013, PMID: 23913798; Leoni et al., 2016, PMID: 27007857; Vegas et al., 2022, PMID: 35170830; Gülsüm Kayhan et al., 2022, DOI:10.5336/caserep.2022-89352). The variants reported in these individuals included a homozygous multi-exon deletion, compound heterozygous splice variants, and three unique homozygous frameshift variants, suggesting biallelic loss of function as the mechanism of disease. Heterozygous carriers of these variants were unaffected. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by the gene’s biochemical function in EDNRA signaling that is shared with two other genes also associated with ACS (GNAI3 and EDN1) (Clouthier et al., 2014, PMID: 24123988). In addition, while craniofacial malformation has not been reported in knock-out mouse models, the knock-out mice do recapitulate other features that have been described in association with autosomal recessive ACS, including impaired visual processing, movement disorders, and sleep disruption (Jiang et al., 1996, PMID: 8962098; Kim et al., 1997, PMID: 9305844; Cheong et al., 2009, PMID: 19955421; Ikeda et al., 2009, PMID: 19898623). 

This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders GCEP on 06/07/2023. It was re-evaluated on 06/30/2025 (SOP version 11). As a result of this reevaluation, the classification increased from Moderate to Definitive with the addition of a case report (DOI:10.5336/caserep.2022-89352).
curationReasonDescription: This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders GCEP on 06/07/2023. It was re-evaluated on 06/30/2025. As a result of this reevaluation, the classification increased from Moderate to Definitive with the addition of a case report (DOI:10.5336/caserep.2022-89352).

evidence.dc:description: Shared function with other genes associated with the phenotype

Variants that disrupt the EDNRA-Gq/11-PLCB4 signaling axis result in 3 subtypes of ACS
GNAI3: ACS type 1 (AD; dominant-negative LOF)
Not curated by ClinGen
Definitive by TGMI|G2P, Moderate by Ambry & Illumina
EDN1: ACS type 3 (AD, AR)
Not curated by ClinGen
Strong by TGMI|G2P, Invitae
EDNRA: mandibulofacial dysostosis with alopecia (AD; ectopic signaling), oro-oto-cardiac syndrome (AD; LOF)
evidence.rdfs:label: EDNRA signaling

evidence.dc:description: No reports of cranial malformation in homozygous KO mice. Across publications describing the KO mice, limited overlap with ACS phenotype: overlap with poor visual attention (1 patient), movement disorder (ataxia vs dystonia (1 patient), disrupted sleep (REM vs central apnea)

Multiple papers characterizing homozygous PLCB4 KO mice:
PMID 8962098: Jiang et al. (1996) 
PLCB4 KO mice show impaired visual processing in a foot shock avoidance conditioning test and reduced amplitude responses on electroretinogram without disruption of retinal morphology 
PMID 9305844: Kim et al. (1997)
Homozygous PLCB4 KO mice show retarded growth, low postnatal viability, seizures, ataxia in the absence of bone malformation or muscle weakness, and small and malformed cerebellums. 
However, the KO mice grew well and survived when not in competition with normal littermates.
PMID 19955421: Cheong et al. (2009)
PLCB4 KO mice experience spontaneous absence seizures 
PMID 19898623: Ikeda et al. (2009)
PLCB4 KO mice show disrupted REM sleep
evidence.rdfs:label: homozygous KO mouse
Leoni 2016 proband VI:7
evidence.detectionMethod: karyotype, microarray, Sanger sequencing of PLCB4 and GNAI3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: question mark ear, post-auricular tag, prominent cheeks, condyle hypoplasia, failure to thrive, swallowing difficulties, constipation, vomiting, glossoptosis, GERD, telecanthus, synophrys, micrognathia, microstomia, bitemporal narrowing, umbilical hernia, poor visual attention, reduced spontaneous motility, opisthotonos, corpus callosum hypoplasia, central & peripheral apnea, mild clitoral hypertrophy

evidence.rdfs:label: El Fizazi 2023 case
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: typical craniofacial ARCND features, in addition to speech delay, intestinal transit defect, macropenis, and hearing loss

evidence.dc:description: Homozygous (consanguinity) missense without functional data; this variant type not yet associated with the recessive form

located in the Y portion of the catalytic domain of the PLCB4 protein, which is where missense variants associated with the dominant form of the disease are located, however, this variant has not been reported in association with the dominant form. 3D protein modeling suggests impacts on protein folding and stability

evidence.rdfs:label: Kido 2013 patient 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: question mark ear, micrognathia, prominent cheeks, obstructive and central apnea, autistic features, macropenis, severe constipation

evidence.rdfs:label: Vegas 2022 patient 23
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: club foot, question mark ear, mild retrognathia, mixed sleep apnea, feeding difficulties necessitating tube feeding, hypotonia, acute hypertonia, dystonia, swallowing difficulties, irregular breathing, nystagmus, developmental delay

evidence.rdfs:label: Gordon 2013 case 8
evidence.detectionMethod: karyotype, array CGH, sequencing of PHOX2B and PLCB4
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: question mark ear, post-auricular tag, micrognathia, microstomia, full cheeks, central apnea, macropenis, swallowing problems, poor suck, GERD, neurogenic changes in tongue, laryngomalacia

evidence.dc:description: multi-exon deletion expected to result in frameshift and premature stop
